awd_titl_txt: Mixed Rod-Coil Polymer Brushes Tailored for Controlled Surface Topography
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

Polymers are long molecules that make up the many kinds of coatings, fabrics and plastics we use. Some polymers can be flexible and soft. Other polymers can be long and stiff. By combining stiff and flexible polymers in a single system formed on a surface, we have learned that we can make nanoscale spiky brush-like surfaces using careful temperature control and coating methods. The PI and his group plan to better understand this surface formation process by making new combinations of soft and stiff polymers, by using advanced tools to study their organization, and by employing computers to model the structure and to predict their behavior. This new way of making surfaces opens up many interesting applications. For example, the surface mimics the protein spikes present on virus surfaces that are used by nature to identify target cells, take part in the entry into the cell, and also to prevent identification by antibodies. These materials can be used to study the behavior of cells on topics ranging from how they work to the behavior of the immune system. Because the spikes are vertically aligned, they may also act as nanowires, so they can be used in energy production and storage systems like solar cells and batteries. Finally, these spikes may be piezoelectric, i.e. they could convert electrical energy to motion (or sound) and motion to electrical energy. This research program will also serve as a mechanism to teach students about polymers and materials science, create globally aware graduate students, and expose students to a collaborative environment. Graduate students will be able to work with the research groups of our collaborators as parts of teams and to take part in exchange visits. Lessons learned from these research programs will be used to teach K-12 students and to be applied in high school teachers' workshops. 


PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Coil polymer brushes synthesized using living radical polymerization methods will be combined with rod brushes with high persistence lengths grown from surfaces made using a variety of living and pseudo-living chemistries. Phase separation aided by solvent processing and guided by nanolithography will be used to control in-plane structure. A variety of chemical and process methods will be used to limit macroscopic phase separation and thereby direct assembly of topographical and chemical structures. Brush growth will employ new, chemically tailored brush initiators for single chain and binary chain growth to form rod-coil mixed brush pairings. To direct brush structure and rod-coil phase separation, brush initiators will be patterned at length scales of a few 10s of nanometers using state-of-the-art lithography methods to control spacing of the brush spikes. Brush organization will be compared to computational predictions which will be used to guide both brush design and selection and to anticipate the resulting physical structure and aid characterization studies. Characterization of the brushes will be made using a selection of analytical methods including grazing incidence (GI) SAXS and WAXS, neutron reflectivity and resonant soft X-ray scattering (RSoXS) measurements. Studies of the conductivity and piezoelectric character of the rod-coil brush films will aid in our understanding of the mixed brush structure. Through collaborations, studies of these materials as cell membrane substrates, for targeted biomolecular binding, as piezoelectric and as conducting materials with unusual transport pathways, will also provide information about key length scales and rod-brush organization. 
.

por.por_cntn:
In this project funded by the Polymers Program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Christopher K. Ober at Cornell University has studied dense polypeptide (polyamide) rigid rod brushes, synthetic polymers made from the building blocks of proteins and enzymes. Polymer brushes are typically attached to surfaces with one end of the chain chemically tethered to a surface. The presence of these chains can dramatically alter surface properties. Nature uses polymer brushes to alter lubrication in joints, to prevent infection, to protect surfaces from contamination and provide many other functions. Polymer brushes have some unique and useful applications including biomedical devices, chemical sensors, or drug-delivery systems. But almost all polymer brushes are soft and floppy and here we wanted to explore what would happen if a very stiff polymer chain were attached to a surface. We studied the effect of this stiffness on organization of the brush surface.

 

Intellectual Merit: In this research, peptide brushes of poly(benzyl glutamate) were grown using a vapor phase ring opening polymerization of its carboxyanhydride from an aminated surface. The resulting helical structure led to dense polymer brushes that are very rigid with persistence lengths in the 100s of nm. When processed in a good solvent, these brush chains stretch out into the solvent and if rapidly placed in a non-solvent (quenched) these same chains aggregate and form a surface covered with tepee like spikes the size of a few microns. We undertook a study to understand how these spikes formed and to determine if we should control the size of these spikes to even smaller dimensions, inspired by the protein (polyamide) spikes found on virus surfaces. We created geometric patterns as small as 50 nm and were able to reduce spike size to that length scale (still larger than the spikes on viruses but potentially useful in sensing and molecular delivery applications). Working with computational scientists, we modelled these brushes and found that spike formation is due to the rapid assembly of brush bundles during the quenching process. Brush length and brush attachment density are critical parameters. Simulation also predicted several morphologies we observed including grid formation with long chains connecting patterned growth sites. Since all chain ends possess an amine function it is possible to attach functional molecules to that amine chain end. The resulting fluorescence studies supported localization of the dye molecules on the chain tip (and therefore the tip of the spike) and suggested a reversible aggregation/disaggregation process that offers the possibility to make sensors and delivery/capture systems.

 

Broader Impacts: This work is highly interdisciplinary in nature and includes international collaboration with researchers in South Korea (theory) and visiting Japanese scholars at Cornell. On a trip home the student involved could not return to the US (caught in COVID boarder closings) but was able to spend several months at Peking University learning new methods of making rod polymers. The research program exposed grad student researchers to a global research interaction and in lab and through outreach activities (Expanding Your Horizons) also serve as mentors and role models to undergraduate students, thus gaining supervisory skills. Undergraduates from Cornell University took part in the research during the academic year while students from other schools participated in research during summer months.
